introduction.p: Torque is related to the ability of a force to rotate a body about some axis. Torque is also called moment of a force.

p.p: Suppose you want to rotate a bolt by fitting a wrench on the head of the bolt and applying a force on the handle of the wrench as in the figure below.
Force \vec F_2 is more effective than \vec F_1 in rotating the bolt since it is applied at a greater distance from the axis of rotation.

introduction.p: The line through the center of the bolt is the axis about which the bolt and the wrench together will rotate. We find that the same force applied on the handle at a larger distance from the axis is more effective than when it is applied nearer to the axis. That is why a longer wrench is more effective than a shorter wrench.
For rotation, we find that the location of the force on the body is as important as the direction and magnitude of the force. Torque is defined to take care of these observations.

In this section, we will define torque of a force precisely and learn to calculate torque. In a later section, we will use torque to quantify the change in rotation that a torque can cause - we will do that through what is sometimes called the second law of rotation.

subsection.title: Torque about a Point

p.p: Suppose a force \vec F acts at some point P. We define the torque of this force about a point O by the vector product of the displacement vector \vec r from O to P and the force. Torque is a vector, which we will denote by script letter, \vec{\mathcal{T}}
If point O, about which the torque is calculated, is fixed during the rotation, then, we say that O is the pivot point of rotation.

subsection.p:
The definition of the cross product gives us the rules for the magnitude and the direction of the torque vector \vec{\mathcal{T}}. You will find those rules explained in the chapter on Vectors.
\amp \text{Magnitude, }\mathcal{T} = r\, F\, \sin\, \theta, \amp \text{Direction of } \vec{\mathcal{T}}: \text{ Use Right Hand Rule}.

To apply the Right Hand Rule here, hold your right hand such that the thumb points in the direction of \vec r and any of the other fingers points in the direction of \vec F, then the torque \vec{\mathcal{T}} will be perpendicular to the two vectors and will be coming out of the palm.

There are other ways of doing the right-hand rule also. For instance, if you point \vec r in the direction of x axis, and \vec F in the xy plane, then \vec{\mathcal{T}} will be in the direction of positive z axis of a right-handed Cartesian coordinate system.

The definition of the cross product also gives us the rules for the components of the torque vector \vec{\mathcal{T}}. Let components of \vec r be (x,\, y\, z) and that of \vec F be (F_x,\, F_y\, F_z). Then the components (\mathcal{T}_x,\, \mathcal{T}_y\, \mathcal{T}_z) of \vec{\mathcal{T}} will be
\amp \mathcal{T}_x = y\, F_z - z\, F_y, \amp \mathcal{T}_y = z\, F_x - x\, F_z, \amp \mathcal{T}_z = x\, F_y - y\, F_x.

subsection.title: The Lever Arm Picture
subsection.p: The lever arm, denoted by symbol r_{\perp}, is the distance from the pivot point to the line of action of the force, where the line of action of the force stands for the infinite line that is along the force vector through the point where force acts.

shows the geometric construction that helps compute the lever arm. We find that lever arm r_{\perp} is
r_{\perp}= r\,\sin\,\theta.

Substituting r_{\perp} for r\,\sin\,\theta in Eq. , we can write the magnitude of the torque vector \vec{\mathcal{T}} more simply as the product of the magnitude of the force and the lever arm.
\amp \text{Magnitude, }\mathcal{T} = r_{\perp}\, F.
The direction of the torque is still obtained the same way as before, i.e., using the right hand rule.

figure.caption: Geometric construction for the lever arm. After indentifying the pivot point O, the force \vec F, and point P where the force acts, we extend the line along which the force acts. Then, we drop a perpendicular from O to the line of force, which is line OQ. The length of OQ is the lever arm of the force. Since \angle \text{OPQ} = \theta, the lever arm, r_{\perp}=\text{OQ} = r\,\sin\,\theta .

subsection.title: The Sense of Rotation and Torque
subsection.p: Torque is nonzero if displacement \vec r and force \vec F are not parallel or antiparallel. These two vectors fall in a plane. The torque \vec{\mathcal{T}} , which is their cross product, must be perpendicular to this plane.
Let \vec r and \vec F are in the xy plane as shown in the two figures below, then, \vec{\mathcal{T}} will either be in the positive z axis direction or in the negative z axis direction.

sidebyside.p: In figure (a) on the right, \vec{\mathcal{T}} is in the positive z axis direction. Now, when you look at the body from the positive z axis direction, i.e., from above the page, it will appear that the force is trying to rotate the body in the counterclockwise sense.

In figure (b) on the right, \vec{\mathcal{T}} is in the negative z axis direction. Now, when you look at the body from the positive z axis direction, i.e., from above the page, it will appear that the force is trying to rotate the body in the clockwise sense.

subsection.p: Thus, we have two ways of indicating the direction of a torque: (1) towards positive or negative z axis, or, (2) counterclockwise or clockwise tendency.

subsection.title: Net Torque
subsection.p: How do you add the influences of two or more torques? Since torque is a vector, the sum of torques will be obtained by the vector sum.

You may recall that if two vectors are in the same direction, you can just add ther magnitudes. You may also recall that if two vectors are in the opposite directions, adding them will result in subtracting the smaller magnitude from the larger magnitude. If two vectors are in some random directions, then, we add them analytically by adding components separately.

In the case of adding torques, the same rules apply. The situation is simpler in fixed axis rotation. If forces and displacements are in the xy plane, then torque will be pointed towards either the positive z axis or the negative z axis. Therefore, in this case, torque will have only the z component nonzero.
\vec{\mathcal{T}} = \mathcal{T}_z \hat k \equiv \left(0,\,0,\,\mathcal{T}_z \right),
where \mathcal{T}_z is positive for torque pointed towards positive z axis (which is same as the counterclockwise sense) and negative if pointed towards negative z axis (which is same as the clockwise sense). That makes adding torques in fixed axis rotation situation just adding up postitive and negative numbers.

A simple example: Suppose we have four torques, \vec{\mathcal{T}}_1 of magnitude 12\text{ N.m} in the counterclockwise sense, \vec{\mathcal{T}}_2 of magnitude 30\text{ N.m} in the clockwise sense, \vec{\mathcal{T}}_3 of magnitude 25\text{ N.m} in the counterclockwise sense, and \vec{\mathcal{T}}_3 of magnitude 15\text{ N.m} in the clockwise sense. We can add all the counterclockwise together and separately add all the clockwise together. Then, subtract the clockwise from the counterclockwise. If the result is positive, the net torque will be counterclockwise and if negative, the net torque will be clockwise. What we are doing here is summing the z components of these vectors.
\mathcal{T}_z^{\text{net}} = 12 - 30 + 25 - 15 = - 8 \text{ N.m}.
Therefore, in this example, \vec{\mathcal{T}}_{\text{net}} has magnitude 8 \text{N.m}, in the negative z axis, which is also stated as clockwise sense.

exercise.title: Torque on a Bar by a Force Acting at an Angle

statement.p: A peg goes through a hole in a metal bar at one end so that the bar can rotate about the peg.

sidebyside.p: A force of 10\text{ N} is applied on the bar at an angle 30^{\circ} to the bar a distance 20\text{ cm} from the peg as shown in the figure.

statement.p: (a) What is the lever arm of the force?
(b) What is the magnitude of the torque?
(c) What is the sense of rotation of the torque?

(d) If positive x axis is in the direction from peg to the where the force acts, and the bar and the force vector are in the xy plane, is the torque in the positive z axis direction or in the negative z axis direction?

hint.p: (a) Use lever arm construction, (b) F\times r_{\perp} , (c) Use right hand rule, (d) use right hand rule.

answer.p: (a) 10\text{ cm}, (b) 100\text{ N.m}, (c) Counterclockwise, (d) positive z axis.

sidebyside.p: (a) Let us draw the line of force and drop perpendicular to the line of force to identify the lever arm in a figure. We need to find the length of OQ. In \triangle \text{OPQ}, we have the angle \angle \text{OPQ} = 30^{\circ}, obtained from using equality of opposite angles.

solution.p:
(b) The magmnitude of the torque is simply the ordinary product of the lever arm and the magnitude of the force.
\mathcal{T} = r_{\perp}\, F = 10\times 10 = 100\text{ N.m}.
(c) Using the diagram, the positive z axis is out-of-page. So, we look at the diagram to get the sense of rotation. This gives the counterclockwise sense.
The right hand rule on \vec r and \vec F gives the direction out of page, which is the direction of the positive z axis.

exercise.title: Torque of Particles Hitting a Flywheel

statement.p: Several particles hit the flywheel from different directions and at different places but with the same force of 5\times 10^{-3}\text{ N} as described below.

In each case find the magnitude of the torque of each force on the flywheel about an axis through the center of the flywheel and perpendicular to the plane of the flywheel, i.e., about the axle at the center.
(a) Particle 1 hits the flywheel right at the center coming from the same direction as the rotation axis.
(b) Particle 2, hits the flywheel right at the center coming from the 30^{\circ} to the rotation axis.
(c) Particle 3, hits the flywheel right 0.2\text{ m} from the center but perpendicular to the flywheel.
(d) Particle 4, hits the flywheel right 0.2\text{ m} from the center in the plane of the flywheel. But the direction of the hit passes through the center of the flywheel.

(e) Particle 5, hits the flywheel right at 0.2\text{ m} from the center in the plane of the flywheel. But the direction of the hit was such that if you draw the line of the particles flight, distance to that line from the center of the wheel is 0.15\text{ m}.

(f) Particle 6, hits the flywheel right at 0.3\text{ m} from the center in the plane of the flywheel. But the direction of the particle's flight was such that had the particle been any further away from the center, it would have missed the flywheel.

hint.p: Use definitions. Note that if force is parallel to axis, there will be no torque about that axis.

solution.title: (a), (b)
solution.p: In both of these cases, lever arm is 0. Hence Torque is zero.

solution.title: (c)
solution.p: The direction of the force is the same as the direction of the axis. Hence, torque is zero. this force cannot cause rotation around this axis.

solution.title: (d)
solution.p: The lever arm is zero. Hence torque is zero.

solution.title: (e)
solution.p:
The description gives the distance from the axis to the line of force, which is what we mean by the lever arm. Thus, the lever arm is given to be r_{\perp} = 0.15\text{ m}. Therefore, the magnitude of the torque will be
\mathcal{T} = r_{\perp}\, F = 0.15\times 5\times 10^{-3} = 0.75\times 10^{-3}\text{ N.m}.

solution.title: (f)
solution.p:
The description gives the distance from the axis to the line of force, which is what we mean by the lever arm. Thus, the lever arm is given to be r_{\perp} = 0.3\text{ m}. Therefore, the magnitude of the torque will be
\mathcal{T} = r_{\perp}\, F = 0.3\times 5\times 10^{-3} = 1.5\times 10^{-3}\text{ N.m}.

remark.p: Do not confuse torque with force. They are entirely different quantities. Some major difference between torque and force to keep in mind are:

ol.li: Torque depends on the choice of the pivot point about which torque is to be evaluated. Force has no such dependency.
Torque and force are perpendicular to each other since torque is defined as the cross product of a displacement vector and force.

There can be torque on a system even when net force is zero. For instance, in (a), the equal magnitude forces act in the opposite directions on the opposite ends of a wheel cancel out resulting in a zero net force, but the net torque about the center is not zero. Actually, the net torque has magnitude 1 \text{ N.m} and direction out-of-page.

Net force an a system may not be zero even when torque is zero. In (b), the equal magnitude forces act in the same directions on the opposite ends of a wheel cancel out resulting in a zero net torque, but non-zero net force. Actually, net force is 20 \text{ N} down.

figure.caption: Net force and net torques are different things. In (a), net force is zero, but net torque is 1 \text{ N.m} in the out-of-page direction. In (b) the net torque is zero, but net force is 20 \text{ N} down.

exercise.title: Computing Net Torque on a Beam

statement.p: A beam of mass 100\text{ kg} is supported by a cable as shown in the figure with \theta = 30^{\circ}. Use L for the length of the beam - it should cancel out in the end.
(a) Find the magnitude of the tension force in the cable by setting net torque on the beam about the point where the beam is fixed to the wall to zero.
(b) What will be the magnitude of the tension force if cable's angle was double, i.e., \theta = 30^{\circ}.
(c) What will be tension if the cable was oriented vertically?

hint.p: (a) Draw lever arm diagrams for weight and tension. Also work with symbols and put numbers in the end. (b) Use general formula found in (a), (c) Use general formula found in (a).

solution.p: (a) Since we will be computing torques about the pivot point O, we disregard all forces on the beam that act at the pivot. Why? Because their lever arms will all be zero and hence their torques will be zero.

This leaves us two forces acting on the beam - (1) the weight of the beam acting at the center of mass of the beam and (2) the tension force in the cable acting at the end the cable is connected to the beam. We now draw these forces and the lever arm pictures of each force.

Let L be the length of the beam. Then, from Figure (a) we immediately see that lever arm of the weight is
r_{\perp}^W = \dfrac{L}{2},
and from Figure (b), from the \triange \text{OPQ}, we find the lever arm of tension is
r_{\perp}^T = L\,\sin\,\theta.
Let M be the mass of the beam. Then, weight is W = Mg . This gives the following for the magnitudes of the two torques:
\amp \mathcal{T}_W = Mg\dfrac{L}{2}, \amp \mathcal{T}_T = T L \sin\,\theta.
To get the net of these two torques, we need to know their directions as well.

We will use the z axis notation for the direction. Let positive z axis is pointed out of page and the forces be in the xy plane. Then, by the right hand rule, we determine that
\amp \text{ The torque of weight is pointed into the page, and,} \amp \text{ The torque of tension is pointed out of the page.}
Therefore, we get the z component of the net torque to be
\mathcal{T}_z^{\text{net}} = \mathcal{T}_W - \mathcal{T}_T = Mg\dfrac{L}{2} - T L \sin\,\theta.
We set this to zero and solve for T .
T = \dfrac{Mg}{2\,\sin\,\theta}.
Now, we use the numbers given to get
T = \dfrac{100\times 9.81}{2\times\sin\,30^{\circ}} = 981\text{ N}.

(b) Since we worked with symbols in our solution, we can just use another value for \theta in Eq. .
T = \dfrac{100\times 9.81}{2\times\sin\,60^{\circ}} = \dfrac{981}{\sqrt{3}}= 566.4\text{ N}.

(c) Since \sin\,90^{\circ} = 1, from Eq. we get
T = \dfrac{100\times 9.81}{2\times\sin\,90^{\circ}} = \dfrac{981}{2}= 490.5\text{ N}.
